summary: The document is a confidential memorandum from February 3058, detailing file checks on American students who traveled from the Moscow Youth Festival to China. It includes assessments of their political affiliations, behaviors, and backgrounds, with some marked for destruction by January 1959. The document provides insights into the political climate of the time, particularly regarding suspicions of communist sympathies among American students traveling abroad. It details individuals associated with the International Workers Order, the Progressive Party, and various youth festivals in the 1950s, including their political affiliations, activities, and interactions with communist and anti-communist entities.
key_findings: The document contains detailed background checks on American students, assessing their political doctrines and affiliations.
Several students are noted for their left-wing or communist sympathies, with some having direct or familial ties to communist organizations.
Some students refused to surrender their passports to Chinese authorities, indicating resistance or political stances.
The document includes personal anecdotes and behaviors of the students, such as mental health issues and violent incidents, adding a personal dimension to the political assessments.
The memorandum is marked as confidential and suggests the destruction of certain materials, highlighting the sensitive nature of the information.
Stella, Genevive's mother, was a member of the International Workers Order and had interactions with the Polish Embassy.
Lorraine Nowacki and Ben Kocel were involved in a campaign under the Progressive Party for rent control extension in Detroit.
Dan O'Connell was noted for his anti-communist stance and his role as the Publicity Director of the United States Youth Festival Committee.
Jacob Rosen was identified as a leftist with communist connections, including his involvement with the Socialist Workers Party and the Communist Party.
Shelby Tucker was recognized for his anti-communist views and refusal to surrender his passport to Chinese authorities.
Margaret Seeger and her family were reported to have communist affiliations, with her father admitting to past Communist Party membership.
Patty and Steve Tyler were described as anti-communist despite their parents' alleged communist activities.
Bob Williamson was noted for his left-wing political leanings and his father's deportation from the U.S. for communist activities.
